Prince Albert, August 16, 1885.

Notice to Creditors.

The creditors of William Stewart, late of Prince Albert, in the North West Territo-
ries, deceased, are respectfully informed that the day of December 1st, 1884, and all others having claims against him, are respectfully requested to send to John Stewart or to the Clerk of the Court House, Prince Albert, their names and signatures, addresses and de-
scriptions of goods, materials, or services rendered, together with a statement of their accounts, and the na-
ture of the description of goods, materials, or services rendered, and immediately after the said 12th day of August of the present year, or before the said 1st day of December next, the same shall be distributed amongst the parties entitled thereto, according to the law of the land, which notice shall have been given in accordance with the provisions of the act of Parliament for the sale of assets or any part thereof to any person of whose claim notice shall have been given, and in default thereof distribution.

John STEWART
Administrator.

By W. H. Gunn
his solicitor.

Dated this 16th day of July 1885.

TELEGRAPHIC.

THE VERY LATEST NEWS BY WIRE

(By Special Telegraph)
December 27th. Notification for the election of a member to the N. W. Com-
mission took place here and at St. Al-
bert today.

The Education candidates are Francis Oliver and Dr. Wilson. Although both are political partisans, the election will not be carried on along party lines. The two
office holders will be elected and go for
Office. The contest will be close.

The candidates for St. Albert are Sam
Cunningham and Joseph Lamontan.
Sam Cunningham will have a strong
purely local issue.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 27th. Hon. Thomas
McGreevy, the Minister of Interior,
has been elected over Mr. Allison, the
Reform candidate, by a majority of 330
votes.

The Hon. Thomas White, accompa-
nied by the Hon. Mr. General, is on his
way to the North West.

See our $10 tweed suits, the best value in the market. Walters & Baker.

Mr. H. G. Davison has purchased the
building lately occupied by Charlie Woodman.

Try the Great Seal and Henry Clay,
the best patent medicines imported,
regarded by T. E. Jackson.

Toilet Soap, Peat and Colgate's
Creme, Perfume, Cologne Toilet Pow-
der, etc., etc., all at Rock's prices.

The third largest point of interest in the Sas-
katchewan Rifle Club was held at their range on Saturday last, when some fine shooting was witnessed. The first prize, a revolver and 200 cartridges, was won by D. Neill; 2nd, R. Neil, $1;
3rd, C. Harris, $1.

A challenge match, East End vs. Mission, will be arranged for shortly, and of which club
maker will be given.

POLICE NEWS

Special constable Harrison, who was immediately arrested some time ago, is now
rapidly recovering.

Sergt. Hooks has left for Edmonton and Const. McNeill has taken his dis-
charge and left for home, but
Const. Fox Davies has gone East on
pass.

A fireproof magazine and warehouse,
for supplies, have been erected at the barracks.

An entertainment in behalf of the
Memorial Fund is to be given at the
Barracks shortly.

The Fort Macleod Gazette says Louis
Riel refused to take the advice of his
advisers, but if possible he knew his
efforts in that direction were evidence of
treason against the Crown. Also
Riel placed himself at the head of a mob
composed of half-breeds and savages, and he
gave them his advice and orders. The
mob then went to the fort and killed the
leader of a band of half-breeds deserves
as much notice as Louis Riel.

The Monocan Crooks say a petition
has been drawn up there to the effect
that the police force should be increased
to take its proper course in the case of
the arch traitor Louis Riel, at present
imprisoned at Regina, and was summarily
signed.

The Sec. Treasurer, of the Lorne Agricultural Society, has received $100 from
Mr. Macdonald, who has promised to
Shipogue, Down sheep, as a special prize.
Also one from Mr. John Macdonald
for $100, and another for $100.

NORTH-WEST NOTES.

SASKATCHEWAN.

Saskatchewan Landing, Aug. 29th.
Chief of Police Stewart, prosecutor in
the late trials, accompanied by W.
H. Gunn, Solicitor, arrived here today to
Batilford, where he will have the honor
to preside at all proceedings now at that
point of the Saskatchewan River. Major
Coxon, N.W.M.P., who was
taken to Regina some time ago, is
about to be released under police escort
and to be tried at Batilford.

Major Coxon, N.W.M.P., who has
been on a tour of inspection through
the northern district, passed here this after-
noon on his way to Regina.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporters.

Iron Tom's Ritters at Clark's Drug Store.

A choice lot of confectionery just re-
ceived, and will have a very good
supply of Warner's sure cure, pills and whale limes, just received by
Mr. D. McGregor left for Humboldt
this week on a business trip.

The census enumerator for this dis-
trict paid us an official visit today.

Unusual Vegetables, including
Celery, Cucumbers and Pills, 25 cents.

The Rev. Dr. Willoughby, of Sask-
atoon, has been squinting for a few days
past.

A good supply of Warner's sure cure,
pills and whale limes, just received by
Mr. D. McGregor left for Humboldt
this week on a business trip.

Mr. J. Cherry's Tooth Paste, Lyons'
Cherry Tooth Paste, Coal Tar Paste,
Sarsaparilla and Tobacco at Clark's Drug Store.

Stewart Ross have received another
large consignment of fresh groceries,
which they will dispose of cheaper than
ever before.

A rifle match was shot between H. B.
Garvin and M. Bourke, of the east end
club, a fine affair, which was won by
Bourke to our great delight.

The steamer North West passed down
the river last Tuesday evening. She
was seen making her trip before she
went into dry dock for the winter.

Mr. T. A. Newman, of Portage la
Prairie, visited Prince Albert
yesterday for a short time. He expressed
himself most pleased with our town.

Rev. Alex. Campbell has been com-
municated to his bed for a few days. He
expects to be able to attend church in
consequence to attend to his duties on Sun-
day.

Mr. Chas. Woodman, of the Columbia
Brewery, is building a new brewery at
the East end, in front of the H. B. Co.'s
mill. He expects to remove into it by
August 1st.

Messrs. T. E. Jackson, Cass. Newell
and Timo Sanderson arrived in town
last night from Regina, where they had
been giving evidence before the
relief prisoners.

Mr. McNeil left by the last mail
for East Maitland, where he goes to
take the place made vacant by the re-
tirement of the Rev. Archdeacon George
Macleod, who is Principal of Emmanuel
College here.

The Monocan Crooks say a petition
has been drawn up there to the effect
that the police force should be increased
to take its proper course in the case of
the arch traitor Louis Riel, at present
imprisoned at Regina, and was summarily
signed.

The Sec. Treasurer, of the Lorne Agricul-
tural Society, has received $100 from
Mr. Macdonald, who has promised to
Shipogue, Down sheep, as a special prize.
Also one from Mr. John Macdonald
for $100, and another for $100.

On Wednesday night a very unfortu-
nate accident happened to a number of
Batoche stage passengers. The stage
which has been occupied by Mr. Sinclair,
merchant tailor, used as a store, and
Mr. Macdonald, who was in Mr. N. A.
Campbell, was removed, but unfortunate-
ly no steps were taken to fill in or
repair the hole.

The next night being very dark, Willard got off
the road and happened into this cellar
window by means of a trick which
would confine him for several weeks to come, and prevent his going
back with his company, should the Bat-
tlefield be attacked by the Indians, as expected.

This seems a most unfortunate ending
up to a man who has passed countless
years in the service of the country, and
should serve as a warning to those who
are responsible for the number of
unfortunate accidents.

No doubt this state of things will be recti-
fied by the municipality, and had the
stage been in better repair, the passen-
gers would have been able to
avoid the damage done.

As to liability under present circumstances we pre-
fer not to offer an opinion.

FRIDAY, SEPT. 4, 1885.

LAND POLICY.

We proceed to take up the subject of the land policy in the Territories at the point where we left off in our last number. Our object is to demonstrate the great disadvantage of the present policy of reservation of odd sections considered with regard to its effects upon the settlement of a country at its initial stage, and in view of the advantages which have come in so far as sufficient progress has been made in sufficient progress to begin to turn their attention to matters affecting communities rather than individuals. That this stage was arrived at in the district under discussion may be gathered from reference to a memorial embodying the requirements of the people drawn up and presented to Sir John A. Macdonald at his own request by the members speaking through Messrs. C. Macdonald and D. H. Macdonald, in which the disadvantages of the position of the Territories as compared with Manitoba—the result of the want of municipal facilities—is brought prominently into view.

Since that time municipal organization has been provided for, but the fact that provincial organization having been still withheld, and consequently the capitulation or other grant given, leaves the district, speaking without a reserve, renders it doubly hard that all such social improvements as have to be paid for directly by the settlers, owing to the reservation of odd sections from settlement, must bear their cost and be defrayed by one half of the number of individuals over whom it would otherwise be spread. Were the improvements spoken of such as could be easily dispensed with for a time the matter would be of minor consequence, but when they include such vital matters as churches, schools, roads, etc., there can be no question as to the necessity for giving the subject our immediate attention. With regard to the matter of providing schools for the children of settlers we have repeatedly spoken most strongly, and the fact that the exhaustion of the Territorial funds for that purpose has thrown the whole onus of their support directly on the people renders it imperative that they should be allowed to take up their homesites in order that they may be able to bear the burden laid upon their shoulders. It must not be supposed, however, that in this most important matter of education the best interest of each individual entitled by the law at present enforced system of scattered settlement is the only one because it has to be remembered that the question of expense is not set aside by these remarks; the fact that in a rural district let the school be located in the most central position possible, the distance to be travelled by children in going to and coming from it, even under the most favorable circumstances, is a very serious consideration in a community where the winters last so long and are of so severe a nature. That distance should be unnecessary, and a school serving a hard district and resembling in some respects the moat in the case of children whose homes are furthest removed from the centre of a school district, it is not asserting too much to say that it practically cannot be made to be accomplished, however reluctantly, to grow up in ignorance—an evil which it is quite superfluous to enlarge upon. The bearing of the system upon the schools has been dwelt upon merely as an illustration of how purely as a matter of expediency applies to churches, nor can there be the slightest difficulty in extending the principle—certain modifications—to everything in the shape of necessary improvements in the shape of necessary communications. Enough has probably been said to show that a change is not only desirable but absolutely necessary, and we may upon a future occasion be able to suggest some means by which it might be made without entailing hardship upon any interested party.

THE CENSUS.

It would perhaps be unfair to assert that the present taking of the census of the inhabitants of the Territories with a view to giving them representation in the Dominion Parliament is a result of the recent rebellion, but the fact that the Government had previously to that unfortunate affair declared its intention of pursuing this course at an early date, but more the less it may possibly be that the census required to be definitely attended to more promptly than would have been the case had nothing of a startling nature occurred to direct the attention of the whole Dominion to our affairs. As the evil has taken place, it is impossible to spend time in regretting what cannot be remedied, but there is every use in trying to manage now to extract all possible good from what has already happened. The Government will find that the people of the Territories, so far from being unwilling, are willing to be thankful for small mercies, if only they understand that there exists an honest desire to do something for them. If other matters commissionerships of the same stamp as Mr. Spencer, who has been appointed to put through the required work in this district, there will be no unnecessary delay, and the census will be completed in due time when we shall be in a position to send down representatives to Ottawa. Our readers may remember that we long ago advised the people to direct all their energies to this one matter, because as we stated when one allowed a hearing in the Dominion House, we still only have to blame ourselves for the selection of unsuitable men to represent us, should we fail to speedily obtain redress of the minor grievances, which seem of so much greater importance to those who suffer from them than to those who give them without explanation of their real significance—from a distance. The North West Council must before long as at present constituted die a natural death, and give place to a new generation of Legislators, and then there will not be much left for the heart of the settler to desire. The only other change of much importance required is the alteration of the electoral districts, whereby we feel sure that we hope to see the new Minister of the Interior before long convinced of. It is quite within the range of possibility that the Government may mistrust the temper of the people, and not be doing enough actively to hasten on the time when they will become a power in Dominion politics—but we believe that if they do us justice now, and do admit that they appear to be justified in this case as in others, especially needed—they will be surprised at the amount of warm support they will receive from the settlers generally. It is very intelligible that men who have come to the Territories from places where they have been trained to enjoy and exercise political privileges should fret under the galling position of being taxed at least as much as their fellow-countrymen yet deprived of equality in other matters, but that matter righted, there is no danger to be apprehended from the class of men who compose the pioneers of the Territories. We sincerely trust that nothing will occur to retard the gathering of the harvest, and the near prospect of obtaining it casts a most cheering light over the naturally resulting gloom of what has occurred in this district.

COMMUNICATIONS.

VERITAS AGAIN.

To the Editor of The Times.

Sir,—In view of the fact that I have not been able to communicate any further in regard to the letter written by Mr. Mackenzie, I am compelled to take this opportunity of making another attempt to bring the matter to your notice. The letter was addressed to Mr. Mackenzie, and I believe that he has received it. I have no doubt that he will be able to give me an answer to my question. I am sure that he will be willing to do so.

Yours sincerely,

J. C. MACKENZIE.

ADDRESS

To Capt. Douglas, of the Steamer Marquis, at Cedar Lake, on her last trip.

The following communication was delivered to Capt. Douglas, of the steamer Marquis, on August 15th at Cedar Lake, on her last trip, by the passengers, who desire to convey their thanks to Capt. Douglas for having been so kind as to place them in the care of the steamer Marquis.

Yours sincerely,

J. C. MACKENZIE.

3RD ST., PRINCE ALBERT, SASK.
SHOOTING MATCH

The First Prize Meeting of the Saskatchewan Rifle Association.

On Tuesday last the Saskatchewan Rifle Association, recently organized, held their first meeting with very gratifying results.

The competitors included members of the B Battery, North West Mounted Police Force, and of course the citizens who formed the association, and the shooting was commenced under very fortunately unfavorable weather of the day, was extremely creditable. As ill luck would have it, that break which was so much needed, after a long continued spell of fine weather had just occurred, and although there was not any rain, the wind was blowing strongly, cold blowing steadily, which increased at times by violent gusts, which made the shooting very difficult.

In the afternoon the discomfort of the competitors was much increased by showers of hail, which although they continued, were very heavy while they lasted. In spite of this the interest remained very much until the finish of the three matches, viz.: The Ladies Match, The Merchants and The Association; which formed the programme of the first day's proceedings.

The ladies prizes were contested for by competitors who were thoroughly equal, and the result will be very closely divided into prizes later and their scores. The total amount of prizes represent a very handsome sum of money, in the circumstances of the settlement considered.

The rewards paid out in actual cash, consist of twenty-five dollars in gold coins articles which formed the other prizes, brought the money value up to a total of $150.

THE CONVENTION.

Of Delegates to Choose a Representative Candidate of the People for the N.W. Mounted Police.

A meeting of a convention of the delegates from each polling district of the electoral district of Lorne, was held at Mr. And. Spence's residence, Red Rock Hill, on Wednesday morning, September 3rd, for the purpose of nominating a candidate for the North West Command.

The following delegates were present: T. E. Baker, W. J. Baker, J. J. Carter and J. F. Kennedy for the Town; Mr. Comrie, Wm. Germond, and And. Spence for the County; A. Goodfellow, S. W. Vanhoven and John Nelson, Col. Beaton, Robt. Allan, Robt. Giles and Mr. James for the Township of Lorne.

Mr. And. Spence was appointed chairman and J. F. Kennedy secretary of the convention.

A committee consisting of A. McBeath, T. E. Baker and R. Giles were appointed to examine credentials, and reported.

On motion of Mr. Giles seconded by Mr. Carter, Messrs. Germond, McBeath and Vanhoven were appointed to draw lots for the purpose of selecting the candidates.

Messrs. G. Ashman, A. Stanfield and Capt. Caplan were appointed scrutineers.

The ballot prepared by the committee was then presented as follows—

1st.—To the best of his ability, for the best interests of the farmers, of this district—endeavouring to crush monopolies, and prevent the formation of a member of incorporated companies, and that we are opposed to the Government appointments merely to neutralise the influence of those of the party opposite. That we want a representative who will—

Moved by A. McBeath, seconded by
